title.rendered: Find Rooms For Rent In Milan, Italy

content.rendered:
Are you looking to visit a city that’s known for its fashion, food, and art? If so, look no further than Milan, which has it all! From Leonardo da Vinci’s The Last Supper, to the Sforza Castle, Milan is known to have a mix of historical and modern architecture that makes the city a unique place to visit. The city offers several magnificent sites and fun-filled activities, and I’ll be covering the best tourist spots, the city’s public transportation, the average rent in the city, and most importantly — where to find cheap rooms for rent in Milan.

If you’re planning to visit the city for a vacation or to visit a friend, keep reading to see where you can find cheap rooms for rent in Milan.

Related: 15 Best Things To Do In Milan

Getting to Know Milan

Milan is known for being the Italian capital of fashion, design and culture. The city is also the financial center of Italy and sits right in the middle of the country’s largest metropolitan area. While Rome is said to represent the “old” Italy, Milan is the “new” Italy, with a contemporary vibe.

Read on to find out more about the average rent in Milan.

Find Rooms For Rent in Milan

Find A Room For Rent In Milan

Milan is a bustling, cosmopolitan city where you can find many great places to feel at home. Rooms for rent in Milan are aplenty and I’ll be listing the best places to find cheap rooms for your next visit.

Average Rent in Milan

Top neighborhoods in Milan

  • Milan City Center: One of the many perks of staying in the heart of the city is that the main attractions are all within walking distance. From Milan City Center you can reach the Duomo, the La Scala Theater and many more incredible tourist attractions by foot. The University of Milan is also located here, so you’ll notice lots of students hanging around enjoying the city.
  • Città Studi, Ventura and Lambrate: These three neighborhoods are ideal for those on a tighter budget because they’re cheaper, but still near the center of the city. These are great neighborhoods to find cheap rooms for rent in Milan, and you can use public transportation to travel to other parts of Milan in just minutes.
  • Navigli and Porta Genova: If you live for the night life, Navigli and Porta Genova are for you! The streets fill with people who like to party once the sun sets. Additionaly, it also hosts the Fiera di Senigallia flea market every Saturday where you can shop for antiques and secondhand items.

Related: Find Rooms for Rent in Rome

Top Universities in Milan

With its world-class educational institutions, it’s no surprise that Milan is a hub of fashion and architecture. Check out these universities that are in high demand with many international students who are looking to study abroad.

Top 5 Universities in Milan:

  • Università degli Studi di Milano (University of Milan)
  • Università Commerciale Luigi Bocconi (Bocconi University)
  • Politecnico di Milano (Polytechnic University of Milan)
  • Università degli Studi di Milano-Bicocca (University of Milano-Bicocca)
  • Università Vita-Salute San Raffaele (Vita-Salute San Raffaele University)

Is Milan safe?

It’s important to always be vigilant when you’re traveling and staying in another city. In Milan, the overall risk is low, but due to the city’s size it’s best to keep your wits about you at all times.

In case you encounter any emergencies, these hotlines will come in handy. 112 can be dialed to report any issues and the operator will direct you to the service that you need, but knowing the direct number to call will ensure help arrives faster, especially where time is critical.

The 911 equivalent in Italy is 113. This number connects you to the state police who can assist you in an emergency. In the case of fires, missing persons, rescues, and first-response operations, dial 115 to reach the fire service (firefighters). For any medical emergency, dial 118 for an ambulance.

Take note of the word, Aiuta/o (a·iù·ta/a·iù·to) which means “help”.

I recommend downloading the following apps for your time in Milan:

  • Where Are U
  • Re-open EU
  • Immuni

Public Transit in Milan

1. Walkability

Milan is a walkable city with a mix of both historic and modern architecture. The famous landmarks and tourist spots can easily be reached by walking. And the city’s efficient metro and tram can easily help you to your destination for when your feet get tired.

2. Roads & Traffic

The roads in Milan are some of the most congested in the country, which is why driving in the city’s center is not recommended. The good news is that with the city’s great metro and tram system, you don’t need a car to get around and find cheap rooms for rent in Milan.

3. Trains

Milan has a great metro system and a tram network, making it super easy for you to find rooms for rent in Milan. The Milan Metro has four lines and 111 stations and is the longest metro line in Italy.

  • M1 (red) stops at the Duomo and San Babila
  • M2 (green) stops at Milano Centrale
  • M3 (yellow) stops at the Duomo and Milano Centrale (the perfect line for tourists)
  • M5 (purple) is combined with regional trains

4. Buses

Milan has around 80 bus local bus lines and a few trolleybus lines (electric buses with overhead wires), making this is a really easy and convenient way to go around the city. Fifteen night travel routes are also available from midnight until 6am, and they depart every 30 minutes — meaning you can get home from your big night out easily and safely.

Restaurants in Milan

  • Ristorante de Giacomo can be found on a residential street near the historical city center. With a relaxing, homely feel to the restaurant, Giacomo is a must-visit when in Milan. They serve simple Italian cuisine — think fresh seafood, pasta, and delicious desserts. Before you go, visit their website to see more of what they offer!
  • Piz only has three pizzas on the menu to choose from: the Margherita, the Delicata Bianca, and the Marinara. This mightn’t seem like much, but each pizza is exceptional and made using high-quality ingredients. Piz is located at Via Torino 34 bay Pasquale pometto. They don’t take reservations, so it’s best to get there early and be the first in line to make sure you don’t miss out! You can check them out here.
  • 28 Posti is the perfect restaurant for a proper “wine and dine” experience in Milan. Located in the Navigli district, 28 Posti offers a wide range of food inspired by the chef’s roots in Procida, an island near Naples. They also serve natural wines to complete their menu, which you can check out here. You can also get your food delivered or make a reservation.

Related: Find Rooms for Rent in Florence

Parks in Milan

Milan is not only remarkable for its architecture and history — but the city also boasts at least 80 public gardens that are perfect for those times when you’re wanting a chilled-out day. And luckily for you, lots of cheap rooms for rent in Milan can be found near these parks.

  • Parco Sempione, near Castello Sforzesco, is the best park to unwind and enjoy the sunshine, with a huge grassy area and plenty of shade.
  • The Giardini della Villa Belgiojoso Bonaparte is a garden with a temple dedicated to love. However, adults can only enter the park if they’re accompanied by children.

Do you know what else Roomi does outside of helping its readers find cheap rooms for rent in Milan? With our ever-increasing lists of rooms and roommates across the world, we help you find your perfect match!

DOWNLOAD THE APP NOW!
